subject: Re: [junit] Newbie question about the best practice for organizing       and running tests
msgSnippet: I agree, a parallel directory structure for test code is probably best. Some reasons to prefer this layout can be found here:
messageBody:
I agree, a parallel directory structure for test code is probably best.
Some reasons to prefer this layout can be found here:

http://www.exubero.com/junit/antipatterns.html#Mixing_Production_and_Test_Code

In Eclipse, you can just right click on the top level test directory, and
select Run As... -> JUnit test. Eclipse will then find all test classes
underneath that directory and run them. I imagine other IDEs have similar
functionality.

To run tests from Ant, you can use the JUnit batchtest runner, which you
can use to select tests based on naming conventions. For example:

<batchtest fork="yes" todir="${reports.tests}">
<fileset dir="${src.tests}">
<include name="**/*Test*.java"/>
<exclude name="**/AllTests.java"/>
</fileset>
</batchtest>

You can find an example of some working Ant scripts demonstrating this at
http://www.exubero.com/asl/

Cheers,
JOe

On Wed, March 25, 2009 2:17 pm, Colin Vipurs wrote:
> David,
>
> One of the easiest ways I've found of doing this is to put your test
> classes
> into a seperate directory which is solely for tests and mirrors the
> package
> structure of your production classes, so you might end up with something
> like:
>
> project/
> src/
> package1/
> package2/
> test/
> package1/
> package2/
>
> You should be able to just select the test directory as the root of your
> test launcher, be it your IDE or ant or whatever.
>
> On Tue, Mar 24, 2009 at 8:36 PM, David Parks <davidparks21@...>
> wrote:
>
>> Hi there, I'm new at JUnit, and just want to start using it with a new
>> project.
>>
>> I'm trying to figure out the best way to easily expand on a set of test
>> classes.
>>
>> It seems like I should configure a TestSuite of some sort. But I'm not
>> sure
>> if I should use the DirectoryBuilder, or if I should manually maintain a
>> class that launches my tests, or use annotations.
>>
>> It looks like there is a way to simply annotate the classes I want to
>> run
>> and then to be able to kick off various test suites. But the docs don't
>> have
>> many examples of this. And it seems like there are many ways to do the
>> same
>> thing.
>>
>> The cookbook just mentions using JUnitCore.runClasses(TestClass1.class,
>> ...), but that doesn't seem very extendable.
>>
>> I'm just looking for a simple best practice. I'd like to not have to
>> update
>> a main() method each time I want to add a new test class. I'd like to
>> simply
>> kick off one or another suite of test classes from my IDE in most cases
>> and
>> get a nicely printed result printed to the console.
>>
>> Thanks!
>> David
